dc:description: Telomerase RNA component (*TERC*) variants were first reported in relation to autosomal dominant dyskeratosis congenita in 2001 (Vulliamy et al., PMID 11574891). *TERC* is a nearly ubiquitously expressed, long non-coding RNA (lncRNA) that complexes with telomerase reverse transcriptase (*TERT*) and is the template used by TERT to add TTAGGG nucleotide repeats to the ends of telomeres. Variants in telomere related genes have been reported to lead to a group of diseases referred to as telomere biology disorders (TBD’s) (PMID 39371255). Features of TBD’s like dyskeratosis congenita (DC) can include but are not limited to shortened telomeres with or without the classic DC mucocutaneous features (reticular pigmentation of the skin, oral leukoplakia, and nail dystrophy), pulmonary fibrosis, hepatic fibrosis, or bone marrow failure. At least one variant has been reported in a family with only pulmonary fibrosis as a diagnosis in a 64 year old proband with no reported cytopenias or other phenotypes related to dyskeratosis congenita (PMID 17460043). Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found no difference in molecular mechanism, inheritance pattern or phenotypic variability. Therefore, the following disease entities have been lumped into one disease entity, dyskeratosis congenita AD 1 (OMIM:127550), pulmonary fibrosis and/or bone marrow failure, telomere related 2 (OMIM:614743). Twenty-five variants (17 SNV’s and 9 indels) that have been reported in twenty-five probands in eleven publications (PMIDs 11574891, 26024875, 21436073, 19760749, 17640862, 19936245, 16990594, 34267850, 21931702, 17460043, 17392301) are included in this curation. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence has been reached. The mechanism of pathogenicity is known to be loss of function leading to shortened telomeres and early cell death. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by mouse models, pull-down assay, and in vitro functional modification assays performed in non-patient cells (PMIDs 26518879, 27587879, 32150348, 11520856, 9335332). In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between *TERC* and autosomal dominant *TERC*-related short telomere syndrome. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen ILD GCEP on the meeting date November 12, 2024 (SOP11).

evidence.dc:description: Score reduced since no +/- recapitulated all of the same phenotypes in the -/- mice and there have been no confirmed biallelic TERC variants found in patients.

The model system mTERC -/- at the time of this publication is an established model that racapitulates the telomere shortening, telomerase activity reducing, hematopoietic phenotypes (aplastic anemia) and genetic anticipation that are also features seen in humans with TERC variants. The publication further shows that rescue of the biallelic mTERC -/- state to an mTERC +/- state by crossing will aleviate the severe phenotypes of the deletion even when the cross occurs with a later generation severely affected line.
evidence.rdfs:label: mTERC -/- rescue

evidence.dc:description: The clearest drop in telomerase activity was in mTERC -/- mice and there are no reports of a confirmed biallelic null/pathogenic TERC variant carrying human proband in the literature. There is also a lack of other phenotypes that would indicate the model recapitulates dyskeratosis congenita or bone marrow failure/pulmonary fibrosis phenotypes.

The mice were totally deficient for both mTERC and assayed telomerase activity as determined by TRAP assay. This is consistent with human probands heterozygous for many TERC variants where measurable decreases in telomere length and telomerase activity have been reported. Only the mTERC -/- mice showed a clear phenotype concerning telomerase activity, with mTERC +/- mice still showing detectable telomerase activity, though that has also been seen in human probands. It should be noted however that there is limited evidence in the literature for humans with biallelic null or pathogenic TERC variants.
evidence.rdfs:label: mTERC -/- mouse

evidence.dc:description: The mouse phenotypes did not include pulmonary fibrosis but did include several findings consistent with human disease.

Alveolar epithelial type II cells (AECII) are found in humans and mice and small populations of this cell type in humans has been confirmed to be telomerase positive. These cells then represent a potential causative mechanism for short telomere induced senescence can lead to pulmonary disease. This study found that in TERC -/- mice, AECII cell numbers decreased significantly and that direct assay of cell senescence via β-gal staining was increased in TERC -/- lung tissue. Further, inflammatory cytokine levels were increased in assayed lung tissue and while the mice did not recapitulate the pulmonary fibrosis phenotype, there were increases in α-smooth muscle actin and collagen 1α1 which according to the authors could be indicative of myofibroblast differentiation, a common finding in fibrotic pulmonary tissue.
evidence.rdfs:label: TERC -/- mouse AECII senescence

evidence.dc:description: Increased score due to virtual absence of telomerase activity and that variant was identified in an affected individual.

TRAP assay followed by ELISA was used to quantify telomerase activity in the cells. The cell line used in the experiment were WI-38 VA13 cells that lack TERC and TERT expression as well as telomerase activity which the authors confirmed before transfection with the variant TERC and wildtype TERT. After transfection with the variant TERT and wild type TERT plasmids, TRAP assay showed a complete lack of telomerase activity, which matched cells without any transfected TERC or TERT plasmid confirming that the variant interrupts telomerase activity.
evidence.rdfs:label: TERC variant TRAP assay

evidence.dc:description: The increased score is due to the experiment being conducted in patient derived iPSC's that not only confirms TERT association with TERC but shows that a TERC variant can interrupt that interaction in a manner independent of another telomerase complex protein, dyskerin.

TERC (telomerase RNA component) provides the template used by TERT (telomerase reverse transcriptase) to add TTAGGG repeats to the telomeres at the end of chromosomes. TERT and TERC physically associate in cells along with many other proteins in what is known as the telomerase complex.
evidence.rdfs:label: Variant TERC/TERT interaction

evidence.dc:description: Absent from gnomAD

Telomere length was found to be in the 5th percentile compared to healthy controls and telomerase activity of recombinantly expressed variant in WI-38 VA13 telomerase deficient cells with wild type telomerase plasmid was 25% of wild type activity levels.
Absent from gnomAD v4.1

Telomere length data was generated for 8/10 variants but there was no clear indication of which variants were included in that analysis. This variant showed decreased telomerase activity, increased cellular concentraion of reactive oxygen species, and induced increased activation of DNA damage response in PMID 38641551.
Absent from gnomAD v4.1
TRAP assay in VA13 cells shows a telomerase activity <2% of WT.
Absent from gnomAD v4.1
Telomerase activity assessed and this variant was found to have approximately 1% activity relative to wild type as expressed as a recombinant protein in telomerase deficient WI-38 cells.

Variant leads to a 35 nucleotide deletion in TERC which which represents a deletion of approximately 6.5% of the ncRNA product and includes the template domain, which combined with the functional data showing a complete lack of telomerase activity justifies default points for a predicted loss of function variant. Absent from gnomAD v4.1

Telomere length was found to be in the 5th percentile of healthy controls and telomerase activity was found to be entirely absent when recombinantly expressed with plasmid expressed wildtype telomerase in telomerase deficient WI-38 VA13 cells.
Absent from gnomAD v4.1

Telomere length confirmed in the 5th percentile and telomerase activity assayed by TRAP determined to be only 10% of wild type when the variant is recombinantly expressed in WI-38 VA13 telomerase deficient cell line supplemented with telomerase encoding plasmid.
GrpMax FAF 0.00005313 in European Non-Finnish population

Telomere length was reported along with all other variants, including TERT variants and most were shorter than age matched controls but not all. TRAP assay in VA13 cells showed telomerase activity ~70% of WT.
Absent from gnomAD v4.1

There is in vitro functional data showing a near fully reduced telomerase activity for the recombinant TERC in cell and the variant was identified as part of a screen that included 52 other genes associated with bone marrow failure. Absent from gnomAD v4.1
Telomere length in the 1st percentile and telomerase activty as assayed by TRAP reported as between 2.2% and 2.7% of wildtype.
Absent from gnomAD v4.1
Short telomere length confirmed by FISH and TRAP assay in VA13 cells showing telomerase activity <10% of WT

The score should be 0 due to the proband being born from consanguineous parents and that the phenotypes reported exhibit genetic heterogeneity. Further, the telomerase activity for this variant was largely preserved compared to wildtype levels of activity. This proband should be acknowledged as the only report of a homozygous variant in TERC. Absent from gnomAD v4.1
Telomerase activity assay shows 92% activity relative to WT so this does not result in the typical LOF associated with this disease.

evidence.rdfs:label: DCR101

member.rdfs:label: DCR101_III:4
member.detectionMethod: Satellite markers used in a whole genome scan and when a locus was identified by linkage analysis using LOD scores, the locus with the highest LOD score was used to define the likely locus of the variant leading to the phenotype and the authors chose to sequence the coding region of TERC (hTR). When no variant was detected, Southern Blotting showed a noticeable deletion. Flanking primers were extended 3' and the boundaries of the deletion were found by sequencing.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Bone marrow failure and aplastic anemia were not asserted however lab values for MCV (mean corpuscular volume), platelets, hemoglobin and white blood cell count are reported for each family member and some values fall well below the provided reference ranges for some family members.

member.rdfs:label: DCR063_II:1
member.detectionMethod: Single gene sequencing of TERC only

evidence.dc:description: Absent from gnomAD v4.1

Functional data on telomere length was generated but for only 8/10 probands and did not clarify which probands were tested. This variant was included in a telomerase activity assay with activity significantly lower than wild type.

The son presented with severe aplastic anemia which is consistent with phenotypes associated with TERC. The father was the index according to the authors but was not included since the father presented with an abnormal karyotype in addition to the TERC variant. Absent from gnomAD v4.1

Telomere length of the index father was found to be very short and telomere activity assay using recombinantly expressed variant TERC in WI-38 VA13 (telomerase negative) cell line showed telomerase activity 1% of wildtype TERC.
Absent from gnomAD v4.1
Telomerase activity assay assessed by TRAP in VA13 cells by transfecting recombinant TERC carrying the variant with activity levels being virtually absent when compared to wild type levels.

This variant was detected by linkage analysis using microsatellite data and TERC was sequenced as the single target gene in the 3q21 to 3q28 region. Further, the only functional data is to show that telomeres are shortened in the affected but given the genetic heterogeneity of that phenotype, a downscore is appropriate. Absent from gnomAD v4.1

Telomere length data assessed by Southern Blot analysis using radio labelled probe followed by restriction digest and gel electrophoresis. Northern blotting suggests that the variant transcript is not produced suggesting haploinsufficiency.
Absent from gnomAD v4.1
Telomerase activity assessed to be <1% of wildtype in VA13 cells
Absent from gnomAD v4.1
Telomerase activity by TRAP in VA13 cells transfected with recombinant TERC carrying the variant shows virtually no telomerase activity when compared to wild type levels.
Absent from gnomAD v4.1
Telomerase activity was virtually abolished compared to wild type control in an in vitro transfection TRAP assay in VA13 cells.
Absent from gnomAD v4.1
Telomere lengths confirmed to be shorter than controls and TRAP assay in VA13 cells showed <1% telomerase activity relative to WT.
Absent from gnomAD v4.1
Short telomeres confirmed by FISH and telomerase activity was assayed in VA13 cells and found in this proband to be <5% of WT.
Absent from gnomAD v4.1
Telomere length data generated for 8/10 probands but the authors did not make clear which of the variants were included in that analysis.
TERC was the only gene screened and the only functional data was reporting the telomere length which is a genetically heterogeneous phenotype. Absent from gnomAD v4.1
Telomere length was assessed by radio labelled probe followed by restriction digest and gel electrophoresis. Telomeres were shorter than age matched controls.
TERC was the only gene screened and the only functional data was reporting telomere length which was shortened in this family but is a genetically heterogeneous phenotype. Absent from gnomAD v4.1
Telomere length was assessed using radio labelled probes followed by restriction digest and electrophoresis. Telomeres were shorter than age matched controls.
Absent from gnomAD v4.1
Telomere length well below controls and telomerase activity assayed by TRAP in transfected VA13 cells found to be <40% of wildtype activity.

The functional data is convincing, however with only two genes sequenced for a genetically heterogeneous phenotype and the chromosome 1 rearrangement, only default points are awarded. Absent from gnomAD v4.1
TRAP assay to determine telomerase activity in VA13 cells shows a complete lack of telomerase activity when the recombinant variant is the only TERC available.

Only two genes sequenced for a genetically heterogeneous phenotypic expression combined with functional data that shows similarities with wild type and known polymorphism activity levels in vitro show that telomere length alone for a variant is insufficient evidence to determine a gene-disease relationship. Absent from gnomAD v4.1

Telomere length showed reduction compared to healthy controls and telomerase activity data showed a similar activity level to both wild type and a known polymorphism, NR_001566.1:n.58G>A (gnomAD MAF=0.055).
